Dear Mr. Donaldson, As I mentioned to you at our recent meeting, there is nn insufficiency of trained local man-power for the large develop ment we have on hand in Kuwait. In view of this position there, it is necessary to look elsewhere for our man-power requirements* and as there are experienced Indians in India available for recruitment by the Kuwait Oil Company, and as we have a number of Indians already in our employment in Kuwait, this source appears to be a good one for our purpose. I have already discussed this with Colonel Hay and Mr. Tandy, and they raised no objection. There will, of course, be a number of problems in connection with the employment of Indians in Kuwait, but I see no reason why these should not be satisfactorily overcome. We already require in Kuwait an Indian ''Yelrare Officer of the British Officer or Indian Civil Service Officer type, and also a recruiter in India who could be attached to our Agents in India, the Anglo-lranian Oil Company (Bombay), to work on our behalf in connection with our recruiting requirements. As there will be a number of Indian Civil Service personnel seeking emnloyment in the near future, I am wondering if you couldassist by passing my request to an appropriate office which might help me in this matter. Should any suitable candidates for these posts be available, I should be glad-to arrange for them to interview e senior member of the Kuwait Oil Company staff, a Mr. L.D. Scott, who will be proceeding to India on our behalf in connection with our problems about the end of January. I do not think that it is necessary for me to indicate at this stage the salary or-terms of employment as these would naturally depend on the qualifications and experience of the candidate. The two appointments are of importance to-the Kuwait Oil Company as the satisfactory organisation of the recruitment and welfare of Indian personnel in Kuwait is of vital importance to the completion of the various stages of the oil development project within the time limits which we have set. The Kuwait Oil Company, any transferee Company and any subsidiary Company that may be created shall be and remain a British Company registered in the British Empire. 2. Notwithstanding anything contained in the Agreement between the Company and the Sheikh the obligations and benefits of that Agreement shall not be transferred to any other Company without the prior consent in writing of His Majesty’s Govern ment, and shall not be transferred to any Company in which more than 50 per cent, of the capital and voting power is directly or indirectly controlled by persons other than British subjects. 3. mods.abstract: The file concerns enquiries into the nationalities of the personnel employed by the Kuwait Oil Company in Kuwait (also referred to as Koweit). The British Government was keen to enforce Article 3 of the Political Agreement dated 5 March 1934 between HM Government and the Company, which stated that the employees of the Company should at all times, so far as was consistent with the efficient carrying on of the undertaking, be British subjects or subjects of the Shaikh of Kuwait. The employment of other nationalities therefore required approval from the British authorities. The papers show that the British were particularly keen to avoid the presence in Kuwait of a large number of American personnel.The papers include quarterly lists of Kuwait Oil Company staff for the period 1935-47 at grades A, B, and C, giving name, designation, nationality, and date of commencement of service; minutes of meetings at the India Office; and correspondence between the company and British officials concerning the employment of individuals (e.g. for geological survey work).The file includes a divider, which gives a list of correspondence references contained in the file by year. This is placed at the back of the correspondence.
